comments.body: It seems all 3 platforms use strings as autofill hints. Why is enum more suitable in this case?

An enum would prevent developers from providing an unrecognized hint string however AutofillConfiguration allows for arbitrary strings

> Using a custom string value is not recommended as it may not be understood by the platform

So using strings here seems OK.

Another couple of sentences that expanded on this a little would help. Developers need to realize that they'll have to study the docs for each hint to understand what platforms the hint applies to and what it means on each platform.

It would also be worth pointing out that this set of hints isn't comprehensive, developers can choose to use hint strings if they know the platform supports them (but we don't recommend doing that).
This begs the question: how do AutofillClient users know when the autofillId field has become non-null?
Can we also add a few more? To me it feels like developers will immediately will need postal-code, country, email to make complete signup page.
I was considering leaving this empty to make this PR easier to review, but that makes it harder to revert. I'll add the complete list of hints then.

I remember we discussed making this step easier to use for the users by using different constructors for the common use cases. We can take advantage of named constructors in dart. Some examples might be:

AutofillConfiguration.newPassword(), AutofillConfiguration.password(), AutofillConfiguration.username(), AutofillConfiguration.email(),

From
```dart
AutofillConfiguration(
  uniqueIdentifier: "identifier",
  autofillHints: <String>[AutofillHints.password],
  currentEditingValue: editingValue,
);
``` 
To
```dart
AutofillConfiguration.password(
  uniqueIdentifier: "identifier",
  currentEditingValue: editingValue,
);
```
it saves one line and it will only be used by people who subclass `AutofillClient`. I think the default constructor should be good enough for now.

I think this API will only be useful for developers that implement their own `TextInputClient`. It's a public API, but most developers don't have to instantiate an `AutofillConfiguration` themselves if they only use `EditableText` or `TextField`.
uber-nit: we usually do not have a blank line between items of a list
looking for a better word for "availability"
I think availability is pretty good choice here. Alternatively you could say "how well they're supported on different platforms".
